240992.name: Retrospective lifetime prevalence of major depressive disorder
240992.datasetName: Retrospective and cumulative prevalence of lifetime depression – Takayanagi et al. (2014)

source.name: Retrospective and cumulative prevalence of lifetime depression – Takayanagi et al. (2014)
source.dataPublishedBy: Takayanagi Y, Spira AP, Roth KB, Gallo JJ, Eaton WW, Mojtabai R. Accuracy of Reports of Lifetime Mental and Physical Disorders: Results From the Baltimore Epidemiological Catchment Area Study. JAMA Psychiatry. 2014;71(3):273–280. doi:10.1001/jamapsychiatry.2013.3579
source.additionalInfo:
This is a longitudinal cohort that was followed up over 4 waves of cross-sectional survey. Wave 1 took place in 1981; wave 2, 1982; wave 3, 1993 to 1996; and wave 4, 2004 to 2005. Only those who remained in the study at wave 4 were included in this dataset. At each wave, participants were interviewed using the Diagnostic Interview Schedule to measure DSM-III or DSM-III-R major depressive disorder. They were asked to describe episodes of depression so far in their lifetimes. Between waves, some people developed depression for the first time. However, other people did not recall episodes that they had described in previous waves. This dataset therefore compares lifetime prevalence based on retrospective recall at each wave versus cumulative recall (across waves of the study).
Failure to recall lifetime mental disorders was defined as not meeting criteria for the lifetime history of the mental disorder at wave 4 despite reporting symptoms that met criteria for that disorder at 1 or more previous waves.

240994.name: Cumulative lifetime prevalence of major depressive disorder
240994.datasetName: Retrospective and cumulative prevalence of lifetime depression – Takayanagi et al. (2014)
